title: Clock ticking on South32 manganese smelter jobs
text:
Hundreds of jobs at South32’s manganese alloy smelter in Tasmania are in the balance as the company continues to weigh up options for the underperforming and ageing asset.

South32 has pushed what shapes as a tough call on the TEMCO smelter, which employs about 250 people, into 2020 as it continues a review of the operations.

The diversified miner is considering closing both TEMCO and its other manganese alloy smelter, Metalloys, in Gauteng, South Africa, because of big shifts in market demand.

Other options include a sale of the smelters or putting them into care and maintenance, while it is understood the Tasmanian Government has offered South32 various incentives to keep TEMCO operating.

South32 suggested a sale was not out of the question despite the TEMCO plant requiring significant work and another big drop in production at both smelters in the first quarter of 2019-20.

“We are assessing divestment options for both Metalloys and TEMCO and we have not yet made a decision on the way forward,” a South32 spokesman said.
description: Tough call on future of TEMCO plant expected early in the new year but the $12.2 billion miner refuses to rule out a sale.
